headline: Ajvar (Serbian Roasted Red Pepper Sauce)
description: Red peppers and eggplant roasted over a wood fire give this sweet and tangy Serbian sauce a pleasing smokiness.
name: Ajvar (Serbian Roasted Red Pepper Sauce)
keywords: easy, eggplant, low carb, pepper, quick, red pepper, sauce
recipeIngredient: 2 pounds red bell peppers (about 5 medium peppers)
5 teaspoons freshly minced garlic (about 5 medium cloves)
1 teaspoon Kosher salt, plus more to taste
Freshly ground black pepper, to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all the charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and arrange coals on one side of the charcoal grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Clean and oil the grilling grate. Place peppers on hot side of grill and cook until blackened all over, 10 to 15 minutes. Transfer pepper to a large bowl, cover with plastic wrap, and let sit until cool enough to handle, about 20 minutes. Remove charred skin, seeds, and cores from peppers.

While the peppers are cooling, pierce skin of eggplant with a fork all over. Place eggplant on cool side of grill. Cover and cook until skin darkens and wrinkles and eggplant is uniformly soft when pressed with tongs, about 30 minutes, turning halfway through for even cooking. Remove eggplant from grill and let sit until cool enough to handle, about 10 minutes. Trim top off eggplant and split lengthwise. Using a spoon, scoop out flesh of eggplant; discard skin.

Place roasted red peppers, eggplant pulp, and garlic in a food processor fitted with a steel blade. Pulse until roughly chopped. Add in oil, vinegar, and salt and pulse until incorporated and peppers are finely chopped.

Transfer sauce to a medium saucepan. Bring to a simmer over medium-high heat, then reduce heat to medium-low and simmer for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally. Remove from heat and season with salt and pepper to taste. Let cool to room temperature then use immediately or transfer to an airtight container and store in refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

review.reviewBody: I'm sorry, but this is Macedonian recipe. Even the Serbian people knows that. And TasteAtlas put it on the list of 100 best dishes of the world on the 63 place, as Macedonian dish. Thank you and cheers ü•Ç!

Red bell peppers make it quite nice but for a bit of zing use hot peppers, or a combination, as you prefer. Don't forget to remove the seeds if you are leery of heat. My Macedonian friend loves the spicy kind.
Recipe looks good, just one correction. This spread is not Serbian per se, it is made and eaten all across the Balkans, from Slovenia to Greece.

Delicious. True ajvarski peppers make a world of difference in flavor. I cranked my pellet smoker to 400¬∞F and ‚Äúgrilled‚Äù them in there. 15 minutes a side for the halved peppers, with an extra 5 minutes for the halved eggplants. It‚Äôs a little obnoxious to peel the paper skin off but important. Had to pay close attention when simmering as there‚Äôs very little water to evaporate so it tends to burp steam.

Plot twist. Ajvar is only served with ƒáevapi to foreigners, and in intention to his subpar grill meat. If the meat is as it should be, you don't want to use anything bar raw onions (tiny chopped and rinsed with cold water to become sweeter) and maybe some young(?) mild clotted cream.

Recipe for the meat "as it should be" - is more diverse as you write. Start with Leskovac grill - Leskovaƒçki ro≈°tilj, Leskovaƒçki ƒáevapƒçiƒái. You need special parts of beef, good quality plus couple of days to mature meat in cold with 2% salt. No onions in it, unless one is cutting corners.
I simply buy it. Hope you find this interesting. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ro≈°tiljijada

Regards, Your fellow foodie.
